newsitem.title: USA: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS -- negative tone seen for day.
newsitem.headline: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS -- negative tone seen for day.

text.p: U.S. municipal bond traders said they expect the tone to turn negative as action gets underway on the new week.

"We've got supply coming in, we're looking for munis to underperform Treasuries," one trader said. A lower government long bond was also seen as a bad omen for Monday's trends. The 30-year bond was lost 4/32 at 97-14/32 to yield 6.83 percent.
Action in the municipal market so far Monday was typically light, as traders said the week's new issue calendar Tuesday would likely be the catalyst for any significant trading.
This week's new issues are expected to total $4.4 billion in 107 sales, according to Reuters Municipal Bond Information Group.
Negotiated offerings total $2.9 billion in 51 sales, with a $709 million Puerto Rico issue through Lehman Brothers topping the list.
On the competitive side, 56 sales totaling 1.5 billion are on the schedule. The largest is a $556 million Pennsylvania deal on Tuesday.
The municipal market on Friday gained about 3/8 point, after the February jobs report hinted at tame wage inflation.
The Labor Deparment reported non-farm payrolls rose 339,000 in February compared to a downwardly revised 247,000 increase in Janaury. Economists had expected a 230,000 rise last month.
In futures action Monday, the June municipal contract was off 4/32 at 114-2/32, while June T-bonds were up 1/32 at 110-4/32. The MOB spread was 126 ticks, narrowing from 131 at the close on Thursday.
Among actively traded secondary market issues, bids on Florida Ports Commission MBIA 5-3/8s of 2027 were down two basis points to 5.81 percent net.
Bids on Ohio Turnpike Commission MBIA 5-1/2s of 2026 were unchanged at 97-1/4, after gaining 1/2 point on Friday.
